sections.title: Introduction to REV Hardware Client
sections.content:
REV Hardware Client is REV Robotics' configuration and diagnostic tool for managing REV devices. It provides a graphical interface for configuring SPARK MAX controllers, updating firmware, and performing diagnostics. Understanding how to use REV Hardware Client is essential for setting up and maintaining REV hardware.

REV Hardware Client is similar to Phoenix Tuner for CTRE devices - it's the primary tool for device configuration and troubleshooting. It connects to your robot over USB or CAN bus and allows you to configure all device parameters.

sections.title: Installing REV Hardware Client
sections.content:
REV Hardware Client is a standalone application that you install on your computer. It's available for Windows, macOS, and Linux.

Download: REV Hardware Client is available from the REV Robotics website or from the REV Hardware Client GitHub releases page.

Installation Steps:
1. Download the installer for your operating system
2. Run the installer
3. Follow the installation wizard
4. Launch REV Hardware Client

System Requirements: REV Hardware Client requires a computer with USB ports (for USB connection) or network connection (for CAN bus connection). Check REV documentation for specific system requirements.

sections.title: Connecting to Devices
sections.content:
REV Hardware Client can connect to REV devices in two ways:

USB Connection:
- Connect SPARK MAX to computer via USB cable
- REV Hardware Client automatically detects connected devices
- Useful for initial setup and configuration
- Fast and reliable connection

CAN Bus Connection:
- Connect to robot over network (robot must be powered and on network)
- REV Hardware Client scans CAN bus for REV devices
- Useful for configuring devices on robot
- Requires robot to be on same network

Finding Devices:
1. Open REV Hardware Client
2. Click "Scan for Devices" or "Find Devices"
3. REV Hardware Client will discover all REV devices
4. Select device from list to configure

Connection Troubleshooting: If devices aren't found, check USB connection, verify robot is powered, check network connection, and ensure devices have valid CAN IDs.

sections.title: REV Hardware Client Interface
sections.content:
REV Hardware Client provides a user-friendly interface for device management:

Main Window:
- Device list showing all discovered REV devices
- Device selection and navigation
- Status indicators for each device

Configuration Panels:
- Multiple tabs for different configuration categories
- Real-time parameter editing
- Apply and save buttons

Status Indicators:
- Device connection status
- Firmware version
- Fault indicators
- Real-time data display

Navigation: Select a device from the list to view and configure its parameters. Each device has multiple configuration tabs for different parameter categories.

sections.title: Device Configuration
sections.content:
REV Hardware Client allows you to configure all SPARK MAX parameters through a graphical interface:

General Configuration:
- CAN ID assignment
- Motor type (brushed/brushless)
- Motor inversion
- Idle mode (brake/coast)

Current Configuration:
- Smart current limit
- Secondary current limit
- Current limit settings

Voltage Configuration:
- Voltage compensation
- Voltage settings

Encoder Configuration:
- Encoder type
- Encoder settings
- Position conversion factors

PID Configuration:
- PID parameters (kP, kI, kD, kFF)
- PID slots
- Closed loop settings

Smart Motion Configuration:
- Max velocity
- Max acceleration
- Motion profile settings

Applying Configuration: After configuring parameters, click "Apply" to save settings to the device. Configuration is stored in the device's non-volatile memory.

sections.title: Firmware Management
sections.content:
REV Hardware Client can check and update firmware on REV devices:

Checking Firmware Versions:
- REV Hardware Client displays current firmware version for each device
- Compare versions to determine if update is needed
- Check REV documentation for latest firmware versions

Updating Firmware:
1. Select device from list
2. Navigate to firmware section
3. Check for available updates
4. Download and install updates if available
5. Follow update wizard

Firmware Compatibility:
- Ensure firmware is compatible with REVLib version
- Check REV documentation for compatibility information
- Update REVLib if needed when updating firmware

Best Practice: Keep firmware up to date to receive bug fixes and new features. However, test thoroughly after updating firmware.

sections.title: Diagnostics and Monitoring
sections.content:
REV Hardware Client provides real-time diagnostics and monitoring capabilities:

Real-Time Data Monitoring:
- Motor output (percent and voltage)
- Current draw
- Bus voltage
- Temperature
- Encoder position and velocity
- PID status and error

Fault Detection:
- Device fault indicators
- Fault code descriptions
- Fault history

Status Information:
- Device connection status
- CAN bus status
- Communication status
- Device health

Data Logging:
- Record device data over time
- Export data for analysis
- Useful for tuning and debugging

Using Diagnostics: Monitor device status during operation to identify issues, verify configuration, and optimize performance.

sections.title: Managing Multiple Devices
sections.content:
REV Hardware Client can manage multiple SPARK MAX controllers simultaneously:

Device List:
- All discovered devices are shown in device list
- Each device shows CAN ID and status
- Select device to configure

Bulk Configuration:
- Configure multiple devices with same settings
- Useful for drivetrains with multiple motors
- Apply configuration to multiple devices at once

Device Organization:
- Devices are organized by CAN ID
- Use descriptive CAN IDs for easy identification
- Document device assignments

Configuration Management: Save and load configurations for easy setup of multiple devices or for sharing configurations with team members.

sections.title: Saving and Loading Configurations
sections.content:
REV Hardware Client can save and load device configurations:

Saving Configurations:
- Save device configuration to file
- Useful for backup and version control
- Share configurations with team members
- Document device settings

Loading Configurations:
- Load saved configuration file
- Apply configuration to device
- Useful for restoring settings
- Quick setup of multiple devices

Configuration Files:
- Configuration files are typically JSON format
- Can be edited manually if needed
- Can be version controlled

Best Practice: Save configurations for all devices and keep them in version control. This ensures you can restore settings if needed and share configurations with team members.
